citation.article-title: A new purple sulfur bacterium from stratified fresh water lakes, Amoebobacter purpurens.

p.s: Description of Amoebobacter purpureus sp. nov.
Amoebobacter purpureus (pur. pur' e. us. L. masc. adj. purpureus purple or purplered)

Individual cells are nearly spherical to oval and belong to one of two size groups: Cells of group I strains are 3.3-3.8 μm wide and 3.5-4.5 μm long; cells of group II strains are 1.9-2.3 μm wide and 2.0-3.2 μm long.
Cells occur singly or in irregular aggregates of up to 40 cells; nonmotile under all conditions.
Contain gas vacuoles in the central part of the cells.
Color of dense cell suspensions purple-red.
Photosynthetic membranes of vesicular type.
Contain baeteriochlorophyll a and carotenoid okenone as major component.
Phototrophic under anaerobic conditions or chemoautotrophic under microaerobic conditions in the dark.
Electron donors used for photoautotrophic growth: hydrogen sulfide, sulfur, thiosulfate.
Globules of sulfur are stored inside the cells as intermediary product.
In the presence of sulfide and bicarbonate, acetate, propionate, pyruvate, lactate and glucose are photoassimilated.
Chemolithoautotrophic growth is possible with hydrogen sulfide and thiosulfate as electron donors.
Incapable of assimilatory sulfate reduction.
Optimum pH 7.0-7.3.
Optimum temperature 23-25°C.
Optimum light intensity 21 μE⋄s-1⋄m-1.
Habitat: Anoxic sulfide containing water of stratified freshwater lakes.
DNA base ratio: 63.4-64.1 mol% guanine plus cytosine.
Type strain: Strain ThSchl2, DSM No. 4197.
